ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: developing a research question, gathering data, writing a report
how to present and write research for non experts, coding in Python and R, data visualization, time management for long-term projects
The research process (identifying a question/gap in the literature, writing a research proposal, writing a thesis/manuscript, making and presenting a poster, etc.)
Problem solving with data. Compute and complexity constrained ML
Statistical method
This will depend on what your thesis is about--for me, I learned a lot about how to visualize data (and... how to navigate ggplot in R)

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: love the open ended options for finding a project

strengths: you get to pursue a topic of interest in depth and improve your coding, data visualization, writing, research skills
weaknesses: experience will depend on your advisor/ mentor, hard to do a substantial amount of research in one semester (with no spring break especially), need to be self-motivated throughout semester to keep working on your thesis

I think this will depend a lot on your project advisor and research project. The process will go much smoother if your advisor is an expert in or works regularly with the ideas in your project and if they are available to meet with you regularly (at least once a week). Even if you get stuck, your advisor is in the best position to help you.
It was hands-off for the most part which I appreciated, but Winston gave me excellent guidance!
Very good overall, freedom to analyze unique data I found interesting

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: all were great
The only difference in this course was the use of Zoom meetings and Gathertown for the poster session. I think both platforms worked fine.
Zoom conversations allowed for good conversations with my Advisor

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: yes - take the thesis class. you have very few milestones in your life. make sure that if you do it, you don't half-ass it. it is an incredibly fulfilling experience.
This capstone project is the alternative to the senior seminar in S&DS. I preferred getting to choose my area of focus and structure the project around other classes!
yes, great capstone

I'd recommend it to anyone who can find an interesting topic, good advisor/ mentor, and is self-motivated! It was a good experience for me for those reasons, and it was nice not to have class time or projects/ psets (which would be the alternative with 425)

Yes, but it is more a matter of personal choice to do a thesis vs. capstone. If you have any interest in research or graduate school (even if in the distant future), I would recommend doing the thesis. It gives you a lot more freedom than a project in the capstone course, S&DS 425 (I took this as a non-capstone for comparison).
Yes. Do it if you have a cool problem and a good dataset
Yes

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: senior project
Meetings with advisor and research partners.
Thesis class, very self-directed
There were no "lectures" but I met weekly with my advisor over zoom to discuss the progress on my research.
Thesis work, no class time
Zoom conversations
Meeting with advisor however often you decide to meet with your advisor
